Tsuruoka Station and Related Organizations Collaborate to Raise Safety Awareness | Yamagata Shimbun
A bicycle classroom was opened as a launch event for the operation, and a collision experiment between a car and a bicycle was conducted. = Shoko Gakuen Automobile Training Center, Tsuruoka City

In recent years, the Tsuruoka Police Department (Director Kagezo Sato) has launched "Operation Zero Bicycle and Bicycle Accidents" in an effort to eliminate bicycle and motorcycle-related accidents, which account for a high proportion of incidents within its jurisdiction.

In addition to promoting awareness of accident prevention with traffic safety organizations within the jurisdiction, the government will work to strengthen the enforcement of violations of bicycle traffic rules.
This year, three traffic fatalities occurred in the department, and a person who was driving a motorcycle or bicycle died.

Although the number of accidents is on a decreasing trend, the percentage of accidents involving bicycles is about 11.7% as of June 30, and the percentage of accidents involving bicycles is about 5.8%, both of which are higher than the prefectural average.
In particular, the percentage of bicycle accidents in the past five years has been higher than the average in the prefecture, and we planned a strategy to break through this situation.
The name of the operation was changed to "bike" and "bicycle" in order to avoid accidents.
More than ever, relevant organizations will be encouraged to provide driving instruction to the elderly and use night-light reflectors in traffic safety classrooms.
The station issued a yellow card (instructional warning card) to warn people to be careful.
The opening ceremony of the operation was held at the Shoko Gakuen Automobile Training Center in Tsuruoka City on October 21.
Approximately 30 people attended, and Mr. Sato said, "I would like to ask for your cooperation to reduce even one tragic accident."
The head of the office explained the policy and the activities of each organization.
Cycling classes will continue to be held as a starting event for the operation.

They demonstrated how different the impacts on the bicycles were when the policeman in the car hit the bicycle with the brake on and when the policeman hit the bicycle without stepping on the brake at a speed of about 55 kilometers per hour.

Koichi Kanauchi, Chairman of the Tsuruoka District Regional Traffic Safety Activity Promotion Committee, said, "I have once again realized the horror of traffic accidents, and I would like to call attention not only to the elderly, but also to young people."

Yahoo! News: Japan detects instantaneous emergence of a crisis from online information and judges deception (JBpress) - Yahoo!
"I want to know where and what kind of disaster or accident occurred as soon as possible!"
This is not limited to news organizations such as television and newspapers, but there is also a strong need for many companies such as social infrastructure companies and local governments.
Specificity, a service developed by Spectee that handles information analysis using AI, responds to this need.
[Picture] Specialized team determines the truthfulness of social media information with alerts from Specti
Now, the means by which people first learn about the occurrence of disasters and accidents has begun to shift from television to online information (social media).
Social media, such as Twitter, has become an important medium for disseminating information immediately after a disaster or accident has occurred.
However, it is difficult to keep an eye on the overflowing information and extract useful information from it manually.

Specti detects information about natural disasters and accidents from social media such as Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook, analyzes the content, determines the truthfulness of the information, and distributes it to the user companies.

"We consider a wide range of events that have a negative impact on social activities to be 'crisis'" (Murakami Kenjiro, CEO), a crisis management support service that visualizes various crises occurring in Japan and overseas.
NHK's use of Specti during the Kumamoto earthquake in April 2016 was the first major use of Specti, and subsequently, recruitment movements spread rapidly among companies.

Not only TV stations and newspapers, but also companies that support social infrastructure such as electricity, gas, and transportation, as well as local governments throughout Japan, are now using Specti.
Analyze the post to determine the type of "crisis" and the place where it occurred
Specti delivers information in four steps: "Collection of information", "Analysis and classification of content", "Title assignment", and "Truthfulness judgement".

Companies that use the system must specify in advance the region in which the information is to be collected (e.g., prefectures, municipalities), and the category of crisis (e.g., disasters and accidents).
Specti collects posts that fall under its designation using an API provided by social media.
It then analyzes and categorizes the text, images, and videos contained in the collected posts.
For example, if there is a video showing a fire engine, black smoke rising from a building, and an orange flame from a room, it is classified as a "fire".
In addition, images of vehicles that have rolled over are classified as "traffic accidents" and images of roads covered with water are classified as "road crown water".
Specti also estimates the location of disasters and accidents.
"We often don't know the location from the post, so we're combining various information to make an estimate," says Murakami.
For example, if a road sign or signboard is projected onto an image or video, information about the place name is extracted from it and matched with the place name database to identify the location.

Macau Casino Supervisory Authority Inspects the Implementation of Anti-Epidemic Measures at Casino Facilities...Presentation of a New-type Coronavirus Negative Certificate at Entry Required (Macao Shimbun) - Yahoo!News

Around 40 casinos in Macau were closed for 15 days from February 5 to 19 due to the outbreak of the new-generation cholera virus (COVID-19), and have resumed operations since February 20 with strict anti-epidemic measures in place.

The Macau Casino Regulatory Authority (DICJ) requires the operating company to protect the health of employees and guests to the maximum extent when reopening, ensuring the distance between gaming (casino) tables, opening adjacent seats in table games (e.g. Baccarat tables can seat three to four people at the same time), and operating slot machines once or twice to reduce the risk of cross-infection.
Disinfection of gaming equipment such as chips is also being strengthened.

Guests are also required to wear a mask at the time of entry, have a thermometer, and present a valid health code (including a recent residence record, contact history with a newborn colonist, symptoms such as fever and cough, and contact information generated by entering the code).
From 0 a.m. on July 15, a negative certificate of a new type of coronavirus nucleic acid test (limited to those issued by a licensed facility in Macao or Guangdong) was also required.

The new requirement to present a negative certificate is based on the relaxation of the boundary measures between Macao and Guangdong Province (with the abolition of quarantine quarantine for 14 days, subject to certain conditions) from 6 a.m. on the 15th, which will be accompanied by preventive measures.

On July 18, DICJ announced that following the change in admission conditions from July 15, DICJ Director General Adriano Ho inspected the implementation of anti-epidemic measures at the casino facilities and held a meeting with representatives of the security departments of six casino operators to reiterate their request to protect the health of employees and guests by thoroughly managing the admission of guests.

The DICJ has indicated that it will continue to conduct strict patrols of the casino facilities, hold regular meetings with the operating companies in accordance with the situation and evaluation, and coordinate the anti-epidemic measures at the casinos as appropriate in accordance with the guidelines of the Government Health Bureau.

Dr. Hayashimatsu, director of the Center for Disease Surveillance and Prevention of the Hygiene Bureau, accompanied the visitors to the casino and gave them instructions on the disinfection of gaming chips and how to keep a safe distance between the seats of electronic casino equipment.

Due to a sharp decline in inbound passengers due to anti-epidemic measures including entry restrictions, cumulative casino sales from January to June this year remained at 337.20 billion Macao pataca (approximately 451.9 billion yen in Japanese yen), down 77.4% from the same period of the previous year.

A bronze statue of Masujiro OMURA (1825-69), one of the 10 great figures of the Meiji Restoration, was found on the 23rd in the minting department of Yamaguchi City, where he was born.
An unveiling ceremony was held in the front yard of the Tsusenji Community Exchange Center, where local and government officials celebrated the completion.
Masujiro was a military scholar, a Western scholar, and a doctor during the late Edo period and the Meiji Restoration.

After becoming a lecturer at Bansho Shirabesho, a research and education institution for Western studies in the bakufu, he opened a private school, Hatoido, in Edo, where he taught Western studies, military science, and medicine.
After returning to the Choshu Domain, he gave lectures on military science at the Meirinkan in Yamaguchi.
The statue focused on Masujiro as an educator.
He stood beside the globe, holding a book in his hand, and gave lectures on Dutch studies.
The statue with the pedestal is about 3 meters high (1.55 meters for the statue) and is said to have been made from the point of view of a disciple who attended Masujiro's lectures.
The design was done by Marie Takami, 27, a descendant of Masujiro's wife, Kotoko, and a local designer.

In 150 years after the death of Masujiro OMURA, the executive committee of the project (chairman Toshi OKAMOTO) which was based on the Chusenji Autonomous Association, collected donations to build the castle.
Approximately 12.8 million yen of purified goods were collected from 1104 people nationwide.
The cost of the project, including the installation of the Yoshina plate, is about 12 million yen.
The remaining donations will be used to maintain and manage the statue.

President Okamoto said, "Masujiro, who has continued to have high aspirations and made great contributions as an educator, is the pride of Furusato, and a bronze statue that will be the hope of the children of the region who will take charge of the future."

It turns out that white paint from Teflon-processed frying pan, heat insulation increases the cooling effect!
it's a big discovery!
This year, the rainy season was marked by an unprecedented amount of precipitation, but the hot summer becomes full-fledged when it is light.
It's hot, it's hot, and even the cooling doesn't work very well.
Global warming is a major global problem, and mankind has narrowed down its wisdom on how to overcome the hot midsummer as comfortably as possible.
One way is to wear thin white clothes.
You don't have to wear black clothes to absorb heat in the summer, do you?
And applying the same principle to the architecture of houses, the number of cases using white paints is increasing.
Even if white is white, it cannot be a coating with a characteristic that reflects more light and does not absorb heat.

Henry Samueli School of Engineering and Applied Science at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) and researchers from the Department of Applied Physics and Applied Mathematics at Columbia University have recently discovered a method for mixing white paints that can most efficiently replenish the sun's heat and improve the cooling effect of the interior of buildings.
We are aiming for early commercialization.
Until now, the white coatings with the highest reflectivity of sunlight used titanium oxide, which has a reflectivity of 85%.
White paints that already use titanium oxide are applied to roofs of buildings in high-temperature environments and are used to block out the sun's heat to increase cooling efficiency.
However, the newly discovered white coating is derived from fluorine resin of polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), which is used in teflon-processed frying pans and so on.
It is a white coating that applies this teflon effect and reflects up to 98% of the sun's rays, enabling significant thermal cuts.
Even in the hot summer, thanks to the white paint using Teflon, it is surprisingly easy to spend indoors without being exposed to the intense heat.
Perhaps such an era is coming soon, isn't it?
I think the roofs of Japanese houses have a lot of dark colors, but will the white system become mainstream from now on?

Strict eye to mobile number transfer, excessive retention.
What about commissions and points?
(New Switch) - Yahoo! News
The Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications is conducting a full-scale review of the Mobile Number Transfer System (MNP), which allows users to change their mobile phone numbers as they are.
At a meeting of experts on 21 March, he outlined his policy to revise the guidelines of the MNP, which had been enacted in 2004.
Specific issues include how MNP fees should be allocated and whether or not to detain transferees.
With opposition from telecommunications companies also expected, attention will be focused on whether it will lead to the promotion of healthy market competition.
All-you-can-change mobile phones are so far away from the darkness of telecommunications companies In 2006, when MNP was introduced, the user fee was 2,000 yen, but now it is 3,000 yen.
The MNP fee revenues of the three major mobile telecommunications companies are estimated at 15.9 billion yen annually.

The Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications listed the current state of MNP at the "Working Group on Verification of Competition Rules (WG)", a meeting of experts to discuss the competitive environment in the telecommunications market.
He also cited the time required for consumers to receive MNP reservation numbers when transferring to other telecommunications companies.
Most of the time, the system is available on the Internet, but due to the operation of the main system, the reception time is usually between 9 a.m. and 8 p.m.
The WG documents clearly stated that all-day response was the principle as the direction for future discussions.
It is also a problem that mobile phone companies try to retain people who want to transfer to MNP by giving them points.
It is based on the judgement that excessive retention can impede fair competition.

Mr. Shunichi Kita of Nomura Research Institute, who serves as a member of the WG, recommends that "we should have time to explain the economic benefits provided, or obtain permission from the user, and issue a number to users who do not consent to it quickly and terminate it.It is important to thoroughly complete this process first."

However, among a series of issues, there is a structural problem concerning MNP fees: "The higher the MNP fee, the more difficult it is for customers to withdraw, so it is difficult to motivate them to actively lower the MNP fee" (a person in charge of the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications).
If an operator takes the lead in lowering MNP fees, there is also a concern that the outflow of customers from the company will increase and that the company's efforts will not be rewarded.
The Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications has pointed out that many countries overseas do not charge user fees for MNP, and it is possible that this will happen in Japan as well.
The Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications intends to summarize the results of the WG as a report around September-October, and then begin the process of revising the MNP Guidelines.
The time frame for the revision is expected to be 21 years or later.
Mobile phone companies are likely to be troublesome, including sales and customer support.
